groovyx.net.http

Class HttpBuilder

  • java.lang.Object
    • groovyx.net.http.HttpBuilder
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Closeable, AutoCloseable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    JavaHttpBuilder

    public abstract class HttpBuilder
extends Object
implements Closeable

    This class is the main entry point into the "Http Builder NG" API. It provides access to the HTTP Client configuration and the HTTP verbs to be executed.

    The HttpBuilder is configured using one of the three static configure methods:

    HttpBuilder configure(Function<HttpObjectConfig, ? extends HttpBuilder> factory)

HttpBuilder configure(@DelegatesTo(HttpObjectConfig) Closure closure)

HttpBuilder configure(Function<HttpObjectConfig, ? extends HttpBuilder> factory, @DelegatesTo(HttpObjectConfig) Closure closure)

    Where the factory parameter is a Function used to instantiate the underlying builder with the appropriate HTTP Client implementation. Two implementations are provided by default, one based on the Apache HTTPClient, and the other based on the HttpURLConnection class. It is generally preferable to use the Apache implementation; however, the HttpURLConnection is instantiated by default to minimize required external dependencies. Both are fully supported.

    The closure parameter is used to provide configuration for the client instance - the allowed configuration values are provided by the configuration interfaces (delegated to by the closure): HttpConfig and HttpObjectConfig.

    Once you have the HttpBuilder configured, you can execute HTTP verb operations (e.g. GET, POST):

    def http = HttpBuilder.configure {
    request.uri = 'http://localhost:10101/rest'
}

def content = http.get {
    request.uri.path = '/list'
}

def result = http.post {
    request.uri.path = '/save'
    request.body = infoRecord
    request.contentType = ContentTypes.JSON[0]
}

    See the HTTP verb method docs (below) or the User Guide for more examples.

    • Constructor Detail

      • HttpBuilder

        protected HttpBuilder(HttpObjectConfig objectConfig)

    • Method Detail

      • configure

        public static HttpBuilder configure(Function<HttpObjectConfig,? extends HttpBuilder> factory)

        Creates an HttpBuilder with the default configuration using the provided factory function (JavaHttpBuilder or one of the other HTTP client implementation functions.

        def http = HttpBuilder.configure({ c -> new ApacheHttpBuilder(c); } as Function)

        When configuring the HttpBuilder with this method, the verb configurations are required to specify the request.uri property.

        Parameters:
        factory - the HttpObjectConfig factory function (JavaHttpBuilder or one of the other HTTP client implementation functions
        Returns:
        the configured HttpBuilder

      • configure

        public static HttpBuilder configure(@DelegatesTo(value=HttpObjectConfig.class)
                                    Closure closure)

        Creates an HttpBuilder using the JavaHttpBuilder factory instance configured with the provided configuration closure.

        The configuration closure delegates to the HttpObjectConfig interface, which is an extension of the HttpConfig interface - configuration properties from either may be applied to the global client configuration here. See the documentation for those interfaces for configuration property details.

        def http = HttpBuilder.configure {
    request.uri = 'http://localhost:10101'
}
        Parameters:
        closure - the configuration closure (delegated to HttpObjectConfig)
        Returns:
        the configured HttpBuilder

      • configure

        public static HttpBuilder configure(Function<HttpObjectConfig,? extends HttpBuilder> factory,
                                    @DelegatesTo(value=HttpObjectConfig.class)
                                    Closure closure)

        Creates an HttpBuilder configured with the provided configuration closure, using the defaultFactory as the client factory.

        The configuration closure delegates to the HttpObjectConfig interface, which is an extension of the HttpConfig interface - configuration properties from either may be applied to the global client configuration here. See the documentation for those interfaces for configuration property details.

        def factory = { c -> new ApacheHttpBuilder(c); } as Function

def http = HttpBuilder.configure(factory){
    request.uri = 'http://localhost:10101'
}
        Parameters:
        factory - the HttpObjectConfig factory function (JavaHttpBuilder or groovyx.net.http.optional.ApacheHttpBuilder)
        closure - the configuration closure (delegated to HttpObjectConfig)
        Returns:
        the configured HttpBuilder

      • configure

        public static HttpBuilder configure(Consumer<HttpObjectConfig> configuration)

        Creates an HttpBuilder using the JavaHttpBuilder factory instance configured with the provided configuration function.

        The configuration Consumer function accepts an instance of the HttpObjectConfig interface, which is an extension of the HttpConfig interface - configuration properties from either may be applied to the global client configuration here. See the documentation for those interfaces for configuration property details.

        This configuration method is generally meant for use with standard Java.

        HttpBuilder.configure(new Consumer<HttpObjectConfig>() {
    public void accept(HttpObjectConfig config) {
        config.getRequest().setUri(format("http://localhost:%d", serverRule.getPort()));
    }
});

        Or, using lambda expressions:

        HttpBuilder.configure(config -> {
    config.getRequest().setUri(format("http://localhost:%d", serverRule.getPort()));
});
        Parameters:
        configuration - the configuration function (accepting HttpObjectConfig)
        Returns:
        the configured HttpBuilder

      • configure

        public static HttpBuilder configure(Function<HttpObjectConfig,? extends HttpBuilder> factory,
                                    Consumer<HttpObjectConfig> configuration)

        Creates an HttpBuilder using the provided client factory function, configured with the provided configuration function.

        The configuration Consumer function accepts an instance of the HttpObjectConfig interface, which is an extension of the HttpConfig interface - configuration properties from either may be applied to the global client configuration here. See the documentation for those interfaces for configuration property details.

        This configuration method is generally meant for use with standard Java.

        HttpBuilder.configure(JavaHttpBuilder::new, new Consumer<HttpObjectConfig>() {
    public void accept(HttpObjectConfig config) {
        config.getRequest().setUri("http://localhost:10101");
    }
});

        Or, using lambda expressions:

        HttpBuilder.configure(JavaHttpBuilder::new, config -> {
    config.getRequest().setUri("http://localhost:10101");
});
        Parameters:
        factory - the HttpObjectConfig factory function (JavaHttpBuilder or groovyx.net.http.optional.ApacheHttpBuilder)
        configuration - the configuration function (accepting HttpObjectConfig)
        Returns:
        the configured HttpBuilder

      • get

        public Object get()

        Executes a GET request on the configured URI. The request.uri property should be configured in the global client configuration in order to have a target for the request.

        def http = HttpBuilder.configure {
    request.uri = 'http://localhost:10101'
}
def result = http.get()
        Returns:
        the resulting content

      • get

        public <T> T get(Class<T> type,
                 @DelegatesTo(value=HttpConfig.class)
                 Closure closure)

        Executes a GET request on the configured URI, with additional configuration provided by the configuration closure. The result will be cast to the specified type.

        def http = HttpBuilder.configure {
    request.uri = 'http://localhost:10101'
}
String result = http.get(String){
    request.uri.path = '/something'
}

        The configuration closure allows additional configuration for this request based on the HttpConfig interface.

        Parameters:
        type - the type of the response content
        closure - the additional configuration closure (delegated to HttpConfig)
        Returns:
        the resulting content cast to the specified type

      • get

        public <T> T get(Class<T> type,
                 Consumer<HttpConfig> configuration)

        Executes a GET request on the configured URI, with additional configuration provided by the configuration function. The result will be cast to the specified type.

        This method is generally used for Java-specific configuration.

        HttpBuilder http = HttpBuilder.configure(config -> {
    config.getRequest().setUri("http://localhost:10101");
});
String result = http.get(String.class, config -> {
    config.getRequest().getUri().setPath("/foo");
});

        The configuration Consumer allows additional configuration for this request based on the HttpConfig interface.

        Parameters:
        type - the type of the response content
        configuration - the additional configuration function (delegated to HttpConfig)
        Returns:
        the resulting content cast to the specified type

      • getAsync

        public CompletableFuture<Object> getAsync()

        Executes an asynchronous GET request on the configured URI (asynchronous alias to the get() method. The request.uri property should be configured in the global client configuration in order to have a target for the request.

        def http = HttpBuilder.configure {
    request.uri = 'http://localhost:10101'
}
CompletableFuture future = http.getAsync()
def result = future.get()
        Returns:
        a CompletableFuture for retrieving the resulting content

      • getAsync

        public CompletableFuture<Object> getAsync(@DelegatesTo(value=HttpConfig.class)
                                          Closure closure)

        Executes an asynchronous GET request on the configured URI (asynchronous alias to the get(Closure) method), with additional configuration provided by the configuration closure.

        def http = HttpBuilder.configure {
    request.uri = 'http://localhost:10101'
}
CompletableFuture future = http.getAsync(){
    request.uri.path = '/something'
}
def result = future.get()

        The configuration closure allows additional configuration for this request based on the HttpConfig interface.

        Parameters:
        closure - the additional configuration closure (delegated to HttpConfig)
        Returns:
        the resulting content

      • getAsync

        public CompletableFuture<Object> getAsync(Consumer<HttpConfig> configuration)

        Executes an asynchronous GET request on the configured URI (asynchronous alias to get(Consumer)), with additional configuration provided by the configuration function.

        This method is generally used for Java-specific configuration.

        HttpBuilder http = HttpBuilder.configure(config -> {
    config.getRequest().setUri("http://localhost:10101");
});
CompletableFuture<Object> future = http.getAsync(config -> {
    config.getRequest().getUri().setPath("/foo");
});
Object result = future.get();

        The configuration function allows additional configuration for this request based on the HttpConfig interface.

        Parameters:
        configuration - the additional configuration closure (delegated to HttpConfig)
        Returns:
        the resulting content wrapped in a CompletableFuture

      • getAsync

        public <T> CompletableFuture<T> getAsync(Class<T> type,
                                         @DelegatesTo(value=HttpConfig.class)
                                         Closure closure)

        Executes asynchronous GET request on the configured URI (alias for the get(Class, Closure) method), with additional configuration provided by the configuration closure. The result will be cast to the specified type.

        def http = HttpBuilder.configure {
    request.uri = 'http://localhost:10101'
}
CompletableFuture future = http.getAsync(String){
    request.uri.path = '/something'
}
String result = future.get()

        The configuration closure allows additional configuration for this request based on the HttpConfig interface.

        Parameters:
        type - the type of the response content
        closure - the additional configuration closure (delegated to HttpConfig)
        Returns:
        the CompletableFuture for the resulting content cast to the specified type

      • getAsync

        public <T> CompletableFuture<T> getAsync(Class<T> type,
                                         Consumer<HttpConfig> configuration)

        Executes asynchronous GET request on the configured URI (alias for the get(Class, Consumer) method), with additional configuration provided by the configuration function. The result will be cast to the specified type.

        This method is generally meant for use with standard Java.

        HttpBuilder http = HttpBuilder.configure(config -> {
    config.getRequest().setUri("http://localhost:10101");
});
String result = http.get(String.class, config -> {
    config.getRequest().getUri().setPath("/foo");
});
        Parameters:
        type - the type of the response content
        configuration - the additional configuration function (delegated to HttpConfig)
        Returns:
        the CompletableFuture for the resulting content cast to the specified type

      • head

        public Object head()

        Executes a HEAD request on the configured URI. The request.uri property should be configured in the global client configuration in order to have a target for the request.

        def http = HttpBuilder.configure {
    request.uri = 'http://localhost:10101'
}
http.head()
        Returns:
        the resulting content - which should always be null for this method

      • head

        public <T> T head(Class<T> type,
                  @DelegatesTo(value=HttpConfig.class)
                  Closure closure)

        Executes a HEAD request on the configured URI, with additional configuration provided by the configuration closure. The result will be cast to the specified type. A response to a HEAD request contains no data; however, the response.when() methods may provide data based on response headers, which will be cast to the specified type.

        def http = HttpBuilder.configure {
    request.uri = 'http://localhost:10101/date'
}
Date result = http.head(Date){
     response.success { FromServer fromServer ->
         Date.parse('yyyy.MM.dd HH:mm', fromServer.headers.find { it.key == 'stamp' }.value)
     }
}

        The configuration closure allows additional configuration for this request based on the HttpConfig interface.

        Parameters:
        type - the type of the response content
        closure - the additional configuration closure (delegated to HttpConfig)
        Returns:
        the resulting content cast to the specified type

      • head

        public <T> T head(Class<T> type,
                  Consumer<HttpConfig> configuration)

        Executes a HEAD request on the configured URI, with additional configuration provided by the configuration function. The result will be cast to the specified type.

        This method is generally used for Java-specific configuration.

        HttpBuilder http = HttpBuilder.configure(config -> {
    config.getRequest().setUri("http://localhost:10101");
});
String result = http.head(String.class, config -> {
    config.getRequest().getUri().setPath("/foo");
});

        The configuration Consumer allows additional configuration for this request based on the HttpConfig interface.

        Parameters:
        type - the type of the response content
        configuration - the additional configuration function (delegated to HttpConfig)
        Returns:
        the resulting content cast to the specified type

      • headAsync

        public CompletableFuture<Object> headAsync()

        Executes an asynchronous HEAD request on the configured URI (asynchronous alias to the head() method. The request.uri property should be configured in the global client configuration in order to have a target for the request.

        def http = HttpBuilder.configure {
    request.uri = 'http://localhost:10101'
}
http.headAsync()

        There is no response content, unless provided by request.when() method closure.

        Returns:
        a CompletableFuture for retrieving the resulting content

      • headAsync

        public CompletableFuture<Object> headAsync(@DelegatesTo(value=HttpConfig.class)
                                           Closure closure)

        Executes an asynchronous HEAD request on the configured URI (asynchronous alias to the head(Closure) method), with additional configuration provided by the configuration closure.

        def http = HttpBuilder.configure {
    request.uri = 'http://localhost:10101'
}
http.headAsync(){
    request.uri.path = '/something'
}

        The configuration closure allows additional configuration for this request based on the HttpConfig interface.

        The response will not contain content unless the response.when() method closure provides it based on the response headers.

        Parameters:
        closure - the additional configuration closure (delegated to HttpConfig)
        Returns:
        the resulting content

      • headAsync

        public CompletableFuture<Object> headAsync(Consumer<HttpConfig> configuration)

        Executes an asynchronous HEAD request on the configured URI (asynchronous alias to head(Consumer)), with additional configuration provided by the configuration function.

        This method is generally used for Java-specific configuration.

        HttpBuilder http = HttpBuilder.configure(config -> {
    config.getRequest().setUri("http://localhost:10101");
});
CompletableFuture<Object> future = http.headAsync(config -> {
    config.getRequest().getUri().setPath("/foo");
});
Object result = future.get();

        The configuration function allows additional configuration for this request based on the HttpConfig interface.

        Parameters:
        configuration - the additional configuration closure (delegated to HttpConfig)
        Returns:
        the resulting content wrapped in a CompletableFuture

      • headAsync

        public <T> CompletableFuture<T> headAsync(Class<T> type,
                                          @DelegatesTo(value=HttpConfig.class)
                                          Closure closure)

        Executes an asynchronous HEAD request on the configured URI (asynchronous alias to the head(Class,Closure) method), with additional configuration provided by the configuration closure. The result will be cast to the specified type. A response to a HEAD request contains no data; however, the response.when() methods may provide data based on response headers, which will be cast to the specified type.

        def http = HttpBuilder.configure {
    request.uri = 'http://localhost:10101/date'
}
CompletableFuture future = http.headAsync(Date){
     response.success { FromServer fromServer ->
         Date.parse('yyyy.MM.dd HH:mm', fromServer.headers.find { it.key == 'stamp' }.value)
     }
}
Date result = future.get()

        The configuration closure allows additional configuration for this request based on the HttpConfig interface.

        Parameters:
        type - the type of the response content
        closure - the additional configuration closure (delegated to HttpConfig)
        Returns:
        a CompletableFuture which may be used to access the resulting content (if present)

      • headAsync

        public <T> CompletableFuture<T> headAsync(Class<T> type,
                                          Consumer<HttpConfig> configuration)

        Executes an asynchronous HEAD request on the configured URI (asynchronous alias to head(Class,Consumer)), with additional configuration provided by the configuration function. The result will be cast to the specified type.

        This method is generally used for Java-specific configuration.

        HttpBuilder http = HttpBuilder.configure(config -> {
    config.getRequest().setUri("http://localhost:10101");
});
String result = http.headAsync(String.class, config -> {
    config.getRequest().getUri().setPath("/foo");
});

        The configuration Consumer allows additional configuration for this request based on the HttpConfig interface.

        Parameters:
        type - the type of the response content
        configuration - the additional configuration function (delegated to HttpConfig)
        Returns:
        the resulting content cast to the specified type wrapped in a CompletableFuture

      • post

        public Object post()

        Executes a POST request on the configured URI. The request.uri property should be configured in the global client configuration in order to have a target for the request.

        def http = HttpBuilder.configure {
    request.uri = 'http://localhost:10101'
}
def result = http.post()
        Returns:
        the resulting content

      • post

        public <T> T post(Class<T> type,
                  @DelegatesTo(value=HttpConfig.class)
                  Closure closure)

        Executes an POST request on the configured URI, with additional configuration provided by the configuration closure. The result will be cast to the specified type.

        def http = HttpBuilder.configure {
    request.uri = 'http://localhost:10101'
}
Date date = http.post(Date){
    request.uri.path = '/date'
    request.body = '{ "timezone": "America/Chicago" }'
    request.contentType = 'application/json'
    response.parser('text/date') { ChainedHttpConfig config, FromServer fromServer ->
        Date.parse('yyyy.MM.dd HH:mm', fromServer.inputStream.text)
    }
}

        The configuration closure allows additional configuration for this request based on the HttpConfig interface.

        Parameters:
        closure - the additional configuration closure (delegated to HttpConfig)
        Returns:
        the result of the request cast to the specified type

      • post

        public <T> T post(Class<T> type,
                  Consumer<HttpConfig> configuration)

        Executes a POST request on the configured URI, with additional configuration provided by the configuration function. The result will be cast to the specified type.

        This method is generally used for Java-specific configuration.

        HttpBuilder http = HttpBuilder.configure(config -> {
    config.getRequest().setUri("http://localhost:10101");
});
String result = http.post(String.class, config -> {
    config.getRequest().getUri().setPath("/foo");
});

        The configuration Consumer allows additional configuration for this request based on the HttpConfig interface.

        Parameters:
        type - the type of the response content
        configuration - the additional configuration function (delegated to HttpConfig)
        Returns:
        the resulting content cast to the specified type

      • postAsync

        public CompletableFuture<Object> postAsync()

        Executes an asynchronous POST request on the configured URI (asynchronous alias to the post() method). The request.uri property should be configured in the global client configuration in order to have a target for the request.

        def http = HttpBuilder.configure {
    request.uri = 'http://localhost:10101'
}
CompletableFuture future = http.postAsync()
def result = future.get()
        Returns:
        the CompletableFuture containing the future access to the response

      • postAsync

        public CompletableFuture<Object> postAsync(@DelegatesTo(value=HttpConfig.class)
                                           Closure closure)

        Executes an asynchronous POST request on the configured URI (an asynchronous alias to the post(Closure) method), with additional configuration provided by the configuration closure.

        def http = HttpBuilder.configure {
    request.uri = 'http://localhost:10101'
}
def result = http.postAsync(){
    request.uri.path = '/something'
    request.body = 'My content'
    request.contentType = 'text/plain'
}

        The configuration closure allows additional configuration for this request based on the HttpConfig interface.

        Parameters:
        closure - the additional configuration closure (delegated to HttpConfig)
        Returns:
        the CompletableFuture containing the future result data

    config.getRequest().setUri("http://localhost:10101");

        public <T> CompletableFuture<T> postAsync(Class<T> type,

                                          Closure closure)

    request.uri = 'http://localhost:10101'
}

    request.uri.path = '/date'
    request.body = '{ "timezone": "America/Chicago" }'
    request.contentType = 'application/json'
    response.parser('text/date') { ChainedHttpConfig config, FromServer fromServer ->
        Date.parse('yyyy.MM.dd HH:mm', fromServer.inputStream.text)
    }
}
Date date = future.get()
